oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cotton Burners on the Borders of SW Tennessee & Mississippi Surprised by Federal Scouts [Near Memphis, Tennessee, 1862 May-June]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published as a wood engraving, Illustrated London News, 9 August 1862

Foreground shows uniformed men burning bales of cotton. The two-story house in middle ground has inscriptions written across the drawing. Mounted uniformed troops gallop into the scene from around the back of the house.

Frank Vizetelly was a British correspondent for the Illustrated London News. He wrote on verso of this image, "Cotton Burners on the border of SW Tennessee and Mississippi surprised by Federal Scouts." Vizetelly described the scene of southern soldiers surprised by Indiana cavalry while destroying bales of cotton as "frightened whites and negroes looked on from the house." The Confederate government had forbidden the sale of cotton to the "enemy" in 1861. In order to prevent their falling into the hands of those who could prosper from its sale, Confederate soldiers sometimes destroyed cotton stores.
